summary.p: Does not want to appear at the court hearing set by [the community of] Rohrdorf. Ulrich [Bullinger] is still in Milan with the Duke, but will hardly have success. Must pay two guilders to the [Zug] city clerk Jakob Kolin. Sends cheese from the Ursern Valley, which he received at New Year from Heini Machar from Silenen. Asks for news due to the war rumors; has little to lose. Would be pleased with a visit.

div.p: Dear brother, know that those from Rohrdorf have set a court date for a week from Monday, and I am supposed to come myself. But I do not want to; for a snake lies hidden in the grass. You, consider what good you think, and advise.
Ulrich is still in Milan, and whatever the Duke does with him today, tomorrow it is a lie, and I fear there is nothing to be gained.
Furthermore, I must pay the city clerk Jakob Kolin 2 guilders by this Tuesday, and he has treated me very kindly, as is usual for the useless crowd of scribes.
I also send you and your old women a piece of cheese from the Ursern Valley. It came to me as a New Year's gift from Heini Machar from Silenen, and see if it makes their teeth chatter.
There is much talk of war among us. If there is any news, write. I am now always well greeted, as there is not much to find in the granary; for the traveler sang empty before the robber.

I would gladly suffer that you and your household were with me. I have killed such a good calf, although I do not send it to you. It happens that it is not strange to you. Do you wish to be appeased in this furious time, in which everything is done recklessly?
Farewell; love the one who loves you, as you are accustomed.
To Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, my brother, in Zurich.
